The log is not important. Feel free to skip it.

If, however, you find your=
self a little mystified about your
test case's behaviour, you have the opti=
on of turning on
the log to get another view on what the test case is doing=
.
Alternately you could run the test in a debugger. Or you could 
start wri=
ting a bunch of hand-crafted logging statements since
logging is sometimes =
more effective than debugging. 
But in some cases the assertion log would a=
lready be logging what 
you need to know without your having to write those=
 statements.

It's just another tool that is sometimes useful. Debuggers
ar=
e important, but you don't have to use them.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com,=
 Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@...> wrote:
>
> On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18,=
 C=E9dric Beust  wrote:
> > > If I have to go through umpteen thousand line=
s of log, I may as well
> > > test everything manually.
> >
> > Nobody says=
 you have to, but the fact that your tests pass doesn't
> > guarantee that =
you are testing what you think you are testing.
> 
> Well. If the log is im=
portant, I have to go through it, or I miss 
> something important. If it i=
s not important (and I don't have to go 
> through it) I can skip it altoge=
ther. So what do you mean when you
say I 
> don't have to go through it?
> =

> > Which is why reports are an integral part of a testing framework.
> 
>=
 For BDD, I agree.
> 
> Robert
>
